citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
* Goats, sheep, and Fallow Deer are intermingled in the back pasture when not on exhibit roaming the park. All the deer
are showing signs of a dull, rough, hair coat along the back. Approximately 20 of the deer have patchy hair loss along
their body, with a mottled appearance to the neck, areas of complete hair loss encircling their eyes and along the top of
the muzzle. Two of the deer (identified as not on exhibit) are thin to extremely thin (visible ribcage, prominent pelvic
bones) with significant (over 75%) hair loss. This type of hair condition/ loss is not consistent with seasonal shedding. The
attending veterinarian has not been consulted nor is there any recorded documentation about the coat or weight loss. The
body conditions, coat appearance and hair loss can be indicators of parasites, nutritional deficiencies, or other underlying
medical conditions. The co-mingling of animals must also be considered for possible transmission of parasites or disease.
Licensee must seek veterinary care for these animals and document all diagnosis/treatments as applicable for review
upon request by the inspector.
** To be completed by: 4/24/24
* Two Bengal tigers (female and male) got into a fight during the early evening on 10/14/23, when the male tiger entered
the female's den. Keepers were present and witnessed the altercation, ultimately separating the cats physically for the
rest of the night. Upon visual examination, the keepers saw no open wounds or blood, evaluating that the male tiger just
appeared "sore'. When they checked on the tigers the next morning, the 17yr. old male tiger was deceased. That is when
the attending veterinarian was notified. Lack of communication in a timely manner could have contributed to the death of
the tiger.
Licensee must ensure that information on problems of animal health, behavior and well- being is conveyed in a timely
manner to the attending veterinarian to help assist in providing the best healthcare possible. (CRITICAL)
** To be corrected by: from this day forward (4/18/24)
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
* Goats, sheep, and Fallow Deer are intermingled in the back pasture when not on exhibit roaming the park. All the deer 
are showing signs of a dull, rough, hair coat along the back. Approximately 20 of the deer have patchy hair loss along 
their body, with a mottled appearance to the neck, areas of complete hair loss encircling their eyes and along the top of 
the muzzle. Two of the deer (identified as not on exhibit) are thin to extremely thin (visible ribcage, prominent pelvic 
bones) with significant (over 75%) hair loss. This type of hair condition/ loss is not consistent with seasonal shedding. The 
attending veterinarian has not been consulted nor is there any recorded documentation about the coat or weight loss. The 
body conditions, coat appearance and hair loss can be indicators of parasites, nutritional deficiencies, or other underlying 
medical conditions. The co-mingling of animals must also be considered for possible transmission of parasites or disease.  
Licensee must seek veterinary care for these animals and document all diagnosis/treatments as applicable for review 
upon request by the inspector.  
 
** To be completed by: 4/24/24 
 
* Two Bengal tigers (female and male) got into a fight during the early evening on 10/14/23, when the male tiger entered 
the female's den. Keepers were present and witnessed the altercation, ultimately separating the cats physically for the 
rest of the night. Upon visual examination, the keepers saw no open wounds or blood, evaluating that the male tiger just 
appeared "sore'. When they checked on the tigers the next morning, the 17yr. old male tiger was deceased. That is when 
the attending veterinarian was notified. Lack of communication in a timely manner could have contributed to the death of 
the tiger. 
Licensee must ensure that information on problems of animal health, behavior and well- being is conveyed in a timely 
manner to the attending veterinarian to help assist in providing the best healthcare possible. (CRITICAL) 
 
** To be corrected by: from this day forward (4/18/24) 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representative.
